@deane_ag good point. Media used that word for the Bobby calf story I recall.
@emily_fear_less Govt doesn't lead innovation usually so not surprised @MPI_NZ use this 13th century word either.
@emily_fear_less not looking for a ephemism. A word that is relevant to the activity. 13th century 'slaughter' is not fit for purpose IMO.
@deane_ag correct, and my point is slaughter is used to discribe other not nice things. We shouldn't refer to our animals bend slaughtered
@mikeonthehills @TheCountry @nzherald conveniently forget the industry that allow the practices
@annegalloway I can see how policy stuff gets hard with academics
@annegalloway that is stuck in tradition thinking sorry. Come up with a new word we don't 'slaughter' our animals sorry.
@annegalloway and we don't kill our animals in these inhumane ways that the old world of 'slaughter' depicts. So let's stop using it!
@annegalloway why stick with a word that's centuries old.
@annegalloway is really. Hear 'slaughter' used all the time in relation to terror events and war crimes

@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki 2/2 taken for granted until there is no more'. Water has value. So value it.
@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki NZ is got a phobia to water 'ownership' tho. 'If you don't value the resource that creates the value, then it is 1/2
@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki a better system is a 'right to use'. Which is more like owning it. It decoupled water from land. Australia has this
@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki some water is traded within irrigation schemes. It's not being 'sold', the consent to take is being traded.
@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki the value the water provides from the consent is capitalised in the land price as you mentioned. They own the land...

@FoxMarama @LukeTipoki. It's not owned. Farmers have a 'consent to take'. Which is more like a lease to use it. So don't own it.
